summary: Heart Disease Analysis web application built using React (TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, React Query). Includes bar charts, scatter plots, pie charts, interactive dashboard with filters, data story with narrative scenes, and a data explorer.
architectural_notes: Built with React (TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, React Query); Flutter was removed per user request
known_issues: No results displayed in the dashboard — data may not be loading correctly

existing_features.title: Build an interactive dashboard page with filter controls for age range, gender, race, diabetes status, and stroke history. Applying any filter updates all visualizations on the page simultaneously.

Implement 10 interactive visualizations using a React-compatible charting library: (1) Bar chart — heart disease prevalence by age group, (2) Bar chart — prevalence by gender, (3) Bar chart — prevalence by race, (4) Pie chart — chest pain type distribution, (5) Scatter plot — age vs. max heart rate colored by diagnosis, (6) Scatter plot — cholesterol vs. resting blood pressure, (7) Bar chart — diabetes and stroke comorbidity rates among heart disease patients, (8) Bar chart — average cholesterol by age group, (9) Pie chart — thalassemia type distribution, (10) Bar chart — exercise-induced angina by gender.

Create a Data Story section with 7 sequential narrative scenes. Each scene presents a key insight accompanied by a focused chart and explanatory text. Users can navigate forward and backward through the scenes.
Build a Data Explorer page that displays all patient records in a searchable, sortable, and paginated table. Users can search by any text field and sort any column ascending or descending.

Apply a professional healthcare-themed visual design throughout the app: clean white and light grey backgrounds, deep teal and crimson red accent palette, medical-style typography, card-based layout for charts, and a top navigation bar linking Dashboard, Data Story, and Data Explorer sections.
Render the generated hero banner image and app logo as static assets from frontend/public/assets/generated and display them in the header and navigation bar respectively.

Inform the user that Flutter is not a supported frontend framework on this platform. The platform exclusively supports React with TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, and React Query for frontend development. The existing Heart Disease Analysis application — including all dashboards, visualizations, data story, data explorer, and healthcare-themed UI — will remain built with React and cannot be migrated to Flutter.

Remove the PlatformInfo page (frontend/src/pages/PlatformInfo.tsx) and its route from the router configuration in App.tsx. The app should return to the original three-route structure: Dashboard, Data Story, and Data Explorer.

Diagnose and fix the data loading issue causing the dashboard charts to render empty. Verify that the backend actor is correctly initialized and reachable from the frontend, that the `useFilteredPatients` and related React Query hooks in `frontend/src/hooks/useQueries.ts` are receiving a valid actor instance from `useActor`, and that the query functions are properly awaiting and returning data. Ensure error and loading states are handled so that failures surface visibly rather than silently showing blank chart areas.

new_feature_requests.summary: 10 interactive visualizations (bar charts, scatter plots, pie charts)
Interactive dashboard with filters for age, gender, race, diabetes, stroke
Healthcare-themed UI with professional medical design

Generate a synthetic heart disease dataset on the backend with at least 500 patient records including fields: age, gender, race, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, resting ECG, max heart rate, exercise-induced angina, ST depression, slope, number of major vessels, thalassemia type, diabetes, stroke history, and heart disease diagnosis (positive/negative).

Revert the application to its Version 1 state: a React/TypeScript frontend with a Motoko backend that generates a synthetic 500-patient heart disease dataset. The frontend must include: (1) an interactive dashboard with filter controls for age range, gender, race, diabetes status, and stroke history that update all visualizations simultaneously; (2) 10 interactive visualizations — bar charts for heart disease prevalence by age group, by gender, by race, average cholesterol by age group, diabetes/stroke comorbidity rates, and exercise-induced angina by gender; pie charts for chest pain type distribution and thalassemia type distribution; scatter plots for age vs. max heart rate colored by diagnosis and cholesterol vs. resting blood pressure; (3) a Data Story section with 7 sequential narrative scenes navigable forward and backward; (4) a Data Explorer page with a searchable, sortable, paginated table of all patient records; (5) a professional healthcare-themed visual design with white/light-grey backgrounds, deep teal and crimson red accents, medical-style typography, card-based chart layout, and a top navigation bar linking Dashboard, Data Story, and Data Explorer.

Ensure the Motoko backend actor in `backend/main.mo` correctly initializes and exposes the synthetic 500-patient dataset on canister startup. Verify that the `getFilteredPatients`, `getAllPatients`, `getDatasetConfig`, and `getDatasetSize` query functions return well-formed, non-empty responses. If the dataset generation logic runs in a postupgrade or init hook, confirm it executes reliably so that query calls made immediately after deployment return data.
